BLUE JAY ORCHESTRA TO
MAKE DEBUT MONDAY
AT MARYLAND
Future Presents Busy Time for Hopkins Syncopators- Will Be in
Richmond Easter

A Hopkins atmosphere will pervade the Maryland Theatre on the
first night of the Blue Jay Orchestra's engagement. Although the
Orchestra will be featured for the
entire week, Monday will be the
big night, for on that evening a
benefit will be staged for the Musical Club and from all present indications the undergraduates are
going to turn out in force. Several box parties have been arranged for the occasion and it is
estimated that a large part of the
audience will be made up of Hopkins men and their friends, all ardent followers of the Blue Jays.
To Have Busy Time
The Orchestra will have a busy
time during their engagement for
this group is in as much demand
as usual from other quarters. Friday night the musicians will do
their share in the concert which
the Musical Club is going to present in Forest Park, before their
act is scheduled at the Maryland;
and Saturday they will provide the
syncopation at a tea dance in the
C. E. Hall between their afternoon
and evening performances. This
tea dance, and one on the following Saturday will be staged by the
Musical Club, and will replace the
usual Saturday night affairs.
The concert which the Musical
Club will present next Friday in
Forest Park will be held in the
Mordecai Gist School for the benefit of the Parent-Teachers Associtaion. The program will consist
of the same numbers that were
given at the Home Concert, but in
order that the Blue Tay Orchestra
may get to the Maryland on time
the program will be rearranged so
that their appearance comes in the
first half of the entertainment.

THE HELLO CUSTOM
In its origin the "hello custom" of all Hopkins men speaking to
each other was meant to assist in the formation of a lasting bond of
friendship among the men of Johns Hopkins. In his assimilation
and inculcation of the principle of the student body, to introduce him
to a custom that is a part of the University itself, it was deemed a
point of wisdom to require the student to speak during the first year
of his residence. Acairdingly, a clause to this effect was inserted in
the Freshman Regulations. Never after the first year, however, is
a man required to speak. In that year most of them forget
that they
are compelled to do so and fall into the habit naturally and pleasantly.
And the habit continues into the later years .brightening for each
individual his surroundings.
Some men are found who do not live up to the spirit of the
"hello." Some are bound tO kick. By this time, however, it is easy
to place most of the men who may be described as "grouches" and
others who do not desire to speak. They can be ignored as they
should be and considered non-existent. They are not worthy of the
thought which might mar a pleasant frame of mind. Also, there are
those who deem it beneath their dignity to speak first and some to
whom speaking is so much trouble, so irritating. If a man does not
care to speak, then why speak to him?
At this period in the year there is met a perceptible slacking in
greetings, which in many ways is natural and must be continued in
that light. The tension of the first semester has broken followed by
the usual period of seeming indifference which only indicates a let
up and a relief and a period of recovery.

students."

bottles, and plates litter the
tables and floor of the room,
but the students are supposed to obey the rule in existence.

A Hopkins atmosphere will pervade the Maryland Theatre on the

entire week, Monday will be the
big night, for on that evening a
benefit will be staged for the Musical Club and from all present indications the undergraduates are
going to turn out in force. Several box parties have been arranged for the occasion and it is
estimated that a large part of the
audience will be made up of Hopkins men and their friends, all ardent followers of the Blue Jays.
To Have Busy Time
The Orchestra will have a busy
time during their engagement for
this group is in as much demand
as usual from other quarters. Friday night the musicians will do
their share in the concert which
the Musical Club is going to present in Forest Park, before their
act is scheduled at the Maryland;
and Saturday they will provide the
syncopation at a tea dance in the
C. E. Hall between their afternoon
and evening performances. This
tea dance, and one on the following Saturday will be staged by the
Musical Club, and will replace the
usual Saturday night affairs.
The concert which the Musical
Club will present next Friday in
Forest Park will be held in the
Mordecai Gist School for the benefit of the Parent-Teachers Associtaion. The program will consist
of the same numbers that were
given at the Home Concert, but in
order that the Blue Tay Orchestra
may get to the Maryland on time
the program will be rearranged so
that their appearance comes in the
first half of the entertainment.

THE HELLO CUSTOM
In its origin the "hello custom" of all Hopkins men speaking to
each other was meant to assist in the formation of a lasting bond of
friendship among the men of Johns Hopkins. In his assimilation
and inculcation of the principle of the student body, to introduce him
to a custom that is a part of the University itself, it was deemed a
point of wisdom to require the student to speak during the first year
of his residence. Acairdingly, a clause to this effect was inserted in
the Freshman Regulations. Never after the first year, however, is
a man required to speak. In that year most of them forget
that they
are compelled to do so and fall into the habit naturally and pleasantly.
And the habit continues into the later years .brightening for each
individual his surroundings.
Some men are found who do not live up to the spirit of the
"hello." Some are bound tO kick. By this time, however, it is easy
to place most of the men who may be described as "grouches" and
others who do not desire to speak. They can be ignored as they
should be and considered non-existent. They are not worthy of the
thought which might mar a pleasant frame of mind. Also, there are
those who deem it beneath their dignity to speak first and some to
whom speaking is so much trouble, so irritating. If a man does not
care to speak, then why speak to him?
At this period in the year there is met a perceptible slacking in
greetings, which in many ways is natural and must be continued in
that light. The tension of the first semester has broken followed by
the usual period of seeming indifference which only indicates a let
up and a relief and a period of recovery.
